course.subject: ENVS
course.name: Environmental Impact and Risk Assessment
course.description: This course gives an overview on the relationships between human health, environment, and sustainable development. Topics include the development and objectives of environmental impact and risk assessment; impacts of environmental quality (including air, water, wastes, ecology) and health risks; assessment and mitigation, public participation; sustainable development. Case studies and guest lectures will be included. For ENVS, LIFS and CHEM students in their third and fourth year of study only.
course.prerequisites: CHEM 1030 OR LIFS 1030

reviews.author: envskindasucks
reviews.title: Forget this if it's not a major requirement
reviews.comment_content:
Course Format: two Lectures (80 minutes each) per week

The following topics were included in the syllabus
- Course Introduction, historic background of EIA
- Overview of EIA process, screening and scoping of a project
- Case study introduction and grouping
- Contents of EIA Report & environmental baseline studies
- Water Quality and baseline monitoring in Hong Kong
- Water Quality Impact Assessment
- Case study: Water Quality Impact Assessment
- Air Quality and baseline monitoring
- Air Quality Impact Assessment
- The ecology of Hong Kong and International and local treaties
- Hong Kong Biodiversity & Ecological survey: Birds of HK (guest lecture)
- Ecological Impact Assessment
- Online reading and learning, with online reading report
- Case study: Ecological Impact Assessment
- Noise fundamentals and Noise control in Hong Kong
- Noise Impact Assessment
- Waste Management in Hong Kong
- Waste Management and Implications in EIA
- Project Monitoring & Auditing

They also provided extra reading materials and references for students and I would recommend reading them or at least skim through the pages. It helps when you do the presentation and the term paper.

Despite the richness of the content, the organization was rather confusing and the topics covered were almost too bland. I would even say the information was overloaded, to the point that it's pleonastic. It was basically of no use to anyone, except for students who REALLY aspire to pursue their careers in this field.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ridiculous.
The professor has a heavy accent with weird breaks and pauses in her speech, which makes it difficult to understand what she's trying to convey.
The content was repetitive, yet useless. She kept stressing the importance of EIA but she almost never mentioned how the predictions and other EIA processes are done properly. Also, the content was too much such that most of the time she skips it and tells us to read them by ourselves.
In addition, the instructions given were not clear. Whenever we ask her questions about the report or presentation, she gives us ambiguous answers.
Basically, I taught myself everything by reading the technical memorandum and by gathering information from EPD.
reviews.comment_grading:
Under special circumstances in this semester, the course assessments have been adjusted as the school canceled the final exams and adapted an online mode of study.

Original course assessment:
Term paper for case study: 20% (group work, in groups of 4-5)
Presentation for case study: 20% (also group work)
Final Exam: 50% (with 10% from online reading report)
Continuous assessment (attendance of lectures, group discussions and presentations): 10%

Adjusted course assessment:
Continuous assessment: attendance: 5%
In-class Quiz: 10%
Project presentation: 30%
Term paper: 30%
Online reading report: 15%
One more online essay: 10%
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy workload. Spent way too much time for a single course that doesn't even deserve it.
20-25 pages for the term paper; 30 minutes group oral presentation; 2 online essays with confusing formats; in-class discussions and quiz... Did I mention the reading?

reviews.author: 淺水健
reviews.title: bad grade course
reviews.comment_content: a basic introduction to environmental impact assessment (EIA) and the EIA process in Hong Kong. The components of an EIA study will be taught, with particular emphasis on ecological impact assessment (EcoIA), fisheries impacts, air and water quality impact assessment, and environmental risk assessment. Comparisons of the EIA system with mainland China and other countries will be made. The objective of the course is to equip students with a working knowledge of EIA for future careers in consultancy engaged in EIA projects or non-governmental organisations reviewing EIA reports.
